item.title: Report E-2024110138
item.description:
Report E-2024110138

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-10T12:20:22+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-11-06
  • City: TUCSON
  • State: AZ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal UTU experienced a UN1805 System Yellow release from a 30-gallon poly drum due to a broken pallet and nail puncturing the drum. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. XPO terminal personnel overpacked the damaged drum into a 30-gallon poly drum and deployed absorbents prior to contractors’ arrival. When the crew arrived onsite, they confirmed approximately 8-gallons or product released to a 10’ x 8’ area of the trailer floor, 15’ x 15’ area of the concrete dock floor, and a 4’ x 4’ area of the concrete lot below the trailer floor. Absorbents and sodium bicarb were deployed and worked into the impacted areas. The impacted absorbents and cleanup debris were then collected and containerized into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2024110043
item.description:
Report E-2024110043

Identified by scraper @ 2024-11-07T12:22:36+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-10-08
  • City: PHOENIX
  • State: AZ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: 10/8 XPO Logistics terminal UPH experienced a UN1993 Unisol Liquid Red BK-50 release from 250-gallon metal tote. ERTS dispatched contractor to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 4-ounces of product released to 1' x 1' area of cardboard on the dock floor. The tote was leaking due to a small pinhole in the body. The tote was patched for future transfer. Crew returned on 10/17 once the new metal tote from the shipper was onsite. The crew transferred the product from the damaged tote into the new one for shipment on. The damaged metal tote was staged to be returned to the shipper. All impacted pads, PPE, and cleanup debris were containerized into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.
